participants.participant: John M. Colglazier, Vice President, Investor Relations and Communications
James T. Hackett, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good day ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2009 Anadarko Petroleum Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jerry and I'll be your coordinator today. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will be facilitating a question-and-answer session towards the end of the conference. As a reminder this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. John Colglazier, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may proceed.

Thank you, Jerry. Good morning everyone and thanks for joining us today for Anadarko's Second Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Joining me on the call today, are Jim Hackett, our Chairman and CEO, and other executives who will be available to answer your questions later in the call. As we do each quarter, we have posted additional information in our Operations Report that is available on our website.

Before I turn the call over to Jim, I will remind you that this presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discuss. You should read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements in our presentation slides, our latest 10-K, other filings and press releases for the risk factors associated with our business.

In addition, we will reference certain non-GAAP measures. So be sure to see the reconciliations in our earnings release and on our website. We encourage you to read the cautionary note to U.S. investors contained in the presentation slides for the call.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim Hackett.

Thanks, John. Good morning everyone. As you saw we reported a great second quarter demonstrating the strength of our operations and Anadarko's differentiating exploration. Among other successes for the quarter, we set a record for sales volumes, significantly reduced our lease operating expenses, prudently managed our capital spending, announced a new Deepwater Gulf of Mexico discovery in June and another one last week, and we strengthened our balance sheet.

Total sales volumes for the quarter came in at 56 million barrels of oil equivalent. This is 4 million barrels of oil equivalent above the midpoint of the guidance we provided last quarter and a 4% increase over the first quarter.

Contributing to this record performance were higher volumes in the Rockies, a run rate of approximately 890 gross cubic feet per day at Independence Hub and higher NGL recoveries partly due to the new cryogenic unit at the Chipeta plant in Utah.

When we announced our first quarter results in May, we mentioned our focus on driving down costs to better align them with the current commodity price environment, and we've made a lot of progress in that front as highlighted in last night's news release. We significantly improved lease-operating expense to $4.26 per BOE, almost a full dollar below the low end of our prior guidance. This achievement represents a 12% per BOE sequential improvement over the first quarter of this year and an 18% improvement over the second quarter of 2008.

In addition to the LOE per BOE gains during the quarter, Anadarko also achieved record drilling efficiencies across our asset areas. In the Southern region drilling records were achieved in 27% of the wells drilled during the quarter. And in the Rockies region the Wattenberg field accomplished a 50% reduction in cycle times allowing us to run fewer rigs and still drill 32 more wells in the first half of 2009 versus the first six months of 2008. This is a testament to the innovation and dedication of our operating organization, which made excellent strides improving the cost structure of our company.

With these efficiencies, we've been able to reallocate our capital such that approximately 25% of total capital expenditures are now dedicated to building upon the success of our worldwide exploration program.

Last week we announced the Vito discovery in Mississippi Canyon block 984, which encountered more than 250 net feet of oil pay in Miocene-age sands. We target prospects with greater than 100 million barrels of oil equivalent of resources, and we are very excited about these initial results on Vito and look forward to working with our partners to determine the timing of an appraisal well. We operate the Vito well with a 20% working interest.

In June, we also announced the discovery at the Samurai prospect located in Green Canyon block 432 about 12 miles north of our Marco Polo platform. The Samurai well encountered more than a 120 net feet of oil pay in several sands, and we expect an appraisal well to be drilled within the next year. We operate Samurai with a 33% working interest.

The drill ship that we use to drill the Samurai discovery, Developer Dolphin, is now on location in West Africa to drill the Venus prospect off the coast of Sierra Leone. The Venus well is one of more than 30 identified prospects and leads on our West Africa acreage position, targeting stratigraphic traps in the Cretaceous trend. It has geological and seismic characteristics similar to our giant Jubilee Field offshore Ghana. Another of these Cretaceous sand play prospects is South Grand Lahou offshore Côte d'Ivoire, which we expect to drill after Venus is TD'd.

From Côte d'Ivoire, we then plan to mobilize the rig to Mozambique to commence that drilling program later this year. Since our last update in May, we have significantly expanded our acreage position throughout the Cretaceous trend offshore West Africa.

Anadarko now holds interest in almost 8 million acres across 10 blocks including the recent farm in offshore Côte d'Ivoire. We will operate seven of the blocks and the vast majority of the prospects currently identified within this emerging play. Our average working interest across the play is approximately 40%.

In Ghana, we expect to continue an active program with appraisal wells planned at Tweneboa, Mahogany-4 and Mahogany Deep. The Mahogany-4 well will test the eastern extent of the Jubilee Complex. And the Mahogany Deep and Tweneboa appraisal wells will further evaluate discoveries announced earlier this year.

We anticipate following these wells with additional exploration tests at Teak, Owo and Onyina, all three located offshore Ghana. In addition to these identified opportunities offshore West Africa, we remain active with our pre-salt drilling program offshore Brazil.

On the BMC-30 block, where we previously announced the pre-salt Lahou discovery, this quarter we plan to conduct drillstem tests in an exploration appraisal well at Lahou-2 testing multiple objectives. The well is located about five miles north of the original discovery well, and we operate the block with a 30% working interest.

We also plan to participate in drilling the Itaipu prospect on BMC-32, where we hold a 33% working interest. Itaipu directly offsets Petrobras' large Jubarte development. It has been reported to hold about 2 billion barrels of oil equivalent in the pre-salt.

Onshore in the United States, we continue to manage capital carefully, while re-allocating some funding toward an expanded Marcellus shale program. We are increasingly encouraged about the potential of this play from our results to-date. We drilled our first operated horizontal well, participated as a non-operating partner in six other horizontal tests, and held interest in three completions during the quarter. We'll continue to prudently ramp up activity and anticipate having three to four operated rigs and eight to 10 non-operated rigs running in the play by the end of 2009.

The early success from our Marcellus activities indicates this play possesses some of the most compelling economics in our onshore portfolio. We are seeing initial production rates of between four and 8 million cubic feet per day and estimated ultimate recoveries of between three and 6 BCF per well. Also appointing a 10% pre-tax rate of return achievable at NYMEX prices as low as $2.50 per million BTUs.

In the Rockies, as mentioned earlier, we completed construction of the second train at the Chipeta plant in Utah. This cryogenic unit has increased gross NGL recoveries from 2,500 barrels per day to approximately 12,000 barrels per day. In our Wattenberg field, work is completed on the White Cliffs oil pipeline to Cushing, Oklahoma, where we are delivering 10,000 barrels per day from this new access to markets for our Wattenberg Liquids. As a result, we anticipate better price realizations of at least $8 per barrel as well additional cost saving and operational efficiencies.

Changing gears, we continue to advance our three mega project developments. In Ghana we conducted a successful drillstem test on the Mahogany discovery well, and it tested approximately 21,000 barrels of oil and 25 million cubic feet of associated gas per day, with results suggesting good reservoir connectivity.

In July, the Ghanaian government approved the Jubilee Phase One plan of development and unitization agreement, and the project remains on track with its accelerated Phase One development schedule anticipated to deliver first oil in late 2010.

In the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, platform modifications began in the second quarter on our Constitution spur as work continues on the Caesar/Tonga development. Preparations are underway to drill two development wells in the area during the third quarter, and we expect the project to remain on schedule to deliver first volumes in early 2011.

At El Merk in Algeria, construction and contract work is moving along very well, and we expect to achieve first oil in late 2011. There is additional information on our second quarter activities and our operations report available on our website. These highlights demonstrate that we've built a portfolio with a robust inventory of opportunities that is capable of delivering significant value to our stakeholders.

We believe that executing upon our exploration program and the mega project developments through the current market environment will add significant value to our company. With that objective in mind, we raised $1.3 billion of equity in May and the fact that our stock traded inside of the dilution factor demonstrated that it was well received and that our stakeholders understand it was the right thing to do to build future value.

We also took additional steps during the quarter to enhance our financial flexibility and liquidity. In early June, we issued $900 million of senior notes consisting of five, 10 and 30 year tranches. Pricing on these securities was very attractive relative to where our bonds were trading in the secondary market at the time. And we used the proceeds of the offerings to retire the remaining $968 million of 2009 debt maturities. At quarter-end, we had $3.5 billion of cash on hand, and no scheduled debt maturities until 2011.

We continue to manage our cost of capital and beginning late last year we entered into a series of forward starting treasury swaps for planned 2011 and 2012 debt refinancings. We established these swaps when treasury yields fell to unprecedented lows late last year

The subsequent expected increase in rates enabled us to monetize cash gains of approximately $550 million this quarter. It was through a process of resetting the rates on the positions, while maintaining protection from material increases in treasury rates prior to the 2011, '12 refinancings.

For the summer months of June, July, and August, we expanded our commodity hedge firm to include additional fixed price natural gas swaps at an average price of $4.18, which when combined with our existing three-way costless collars for 2009, provides us with price protection on approximately 80% of our anticipated natural gas volumes over this time period. These swaps have been in the money thus far. We also substantially increased our 2010 derivative positions for both natural gas and crude oil using costless three-way collars.

For natural gas, we have protected more than 75% of our anticipated 2010 volumes with a middle floor of about $5.60 and an upper ceiling of about $8.25. For crude oil we've protected about 50% of our anticipated volumes in 2010, with a middle floor of about $62 and a ceiling of approximately $84. Our current derivative position including basis swaps and firm transportation is attached to last night's earnings new release.

For the quarter, we reported a net loss of $0.47 per diluted share with items affecting comparability that are broken out in the tables attached to last night's news release. In total, these items reduced our net loss by $0.09 per diluted share.

Discretionary cash flow from continuing operations totaled approximately $1.55 billion benefiting from the cash generated by the previously mentioned treasury rate swap resets and the ability to use our 2009 net operating losses as a carry-back to prior periods.

Looking ahead, we are increasing the midpoint of our sales volume guidance for the full year by 2.5 million barrels of oil equivalent. As we have done in the past, we are providing a risk operating profile for Q3 and Q4 that accounts for scheduled maintenance and potential hurricane-related downtime. For example, we expect Independence Hub to be running at reduced rates throughout the remainder of this quarter, as we plan to perform some scheduled maintenance on the allocation separators.

The performance of the company and its people are the basis for much excitement today. The portfolio we've created is truly generating the value we always believed that it could, even in a challenging financial and commodity environment. We expect sales volumes to be at least 3% higher than 2008, and we expect to spend to about 30% less on our near-term projects in 2009 relative to the previous year. Our employees are maintaining a tight focus on controlling costs and improving efficiencies, as you can see from the strong operating results that include record production, significantly reduced costs, six announced deepwater discoveries and a strong, deep inventory of world-class exploration and appraisal activities to test this year and beyond.

Whether it's offshore Sierra Leone, Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana, Brazil, Mozambique, South East Asia, the Gulf of Mexico, or onshore in the U.S., we have substantial option value and superior upside to grow our company.
At this time, we are joined by the executive team and we look forward to taking your questions. So Jerry if you could open up the lines?
And your first question comes from the line of Ben Dell with Bernstein. Please proceed.
Good morning.
Good morning, Ben.

I guess my first question, really I wanted to focus on Sierra Leone and Liberia. On the Venus well, what's your, do you have a rough estimate of the pre-drill that you are using and for the expected reserves? And I guess my follow-up question to that is what are the biggest risk factors on the well? Is it source, sale or reservoir?

Okay Ben, this is Bob Daniels. I guess the best way to put the Venus prospect is, it's the same order of magnitude scale of what Jubilee was when we did the pre-drill on it. Aerially the reservoir thickness that we anticipate over there, the trap configuration, it's all the same. So it's that same order of magnitude of a target. Our biggest risk over there is probably going to be timing of hydrocarbon generation and migration into it. We know we've got the source rock up there. It's just going to be when did it generate and what phase did it generate and did it migrate effectively into this fan complex that we have identified.

Okay, great and my second question was really around the cost base. Obviously with U.S service players and drillers basically generating no earnings, how much additional downside do you believe there is to day rates and service staff as you put pressure on the suppliers right now, or are they – they pushing back that they are already earning very little?

Ben this is Chuck, Ben. What we have seen is a substantial reduction in the cost base that we have had. It's region or area-specific, basin-specific, and my sense is that there is still some additional room to go in certain areas, but we are getting down to where the competitive nature of the basins are determining prices that we will achieve. And my suspicion is we may get another, 0 to 10% of reduction in certain areas, but other areas, particularly like the Gulf of Mexico Deepwater, continue to show some strength.
Okay, great. Thank you.
And your next question comes from line of Subash Chandra with Jefferies. Please proceed.

Yeah, hi good morning. Two quick ones here, on the Eagle Ford, any comment on, I guess almost a half a dozen wells that have been drilled, how many of them have been producing, length of time and how the wells might have held up? And second, on the cash balances on hand, pretty enormous. What plans are with that and if there are further things you might do to sell down interest and raise more cash by year-end?

Yes, Subash I'll go ahead and start with the Eagle Ford. I guess the way to put a frame around the Eagle Ford right now is that we are very encouraged about it, but it's real early. We've got the six wells that you mentioned. We have seen rates as high as 6 million equivalent out of some of those horizontals. From the Eagle Ford, we also have a pierce hole zone that we're testing out there.

We've been up to 10 million a day, but what we are seeing is that some of the infrastructure is not adequate to really get good long-term data on these things, like the pierce hole well is way choked back because of the gathering system out there. So we are having to build that out, so that we can get the information we need. So, I guess to-date right now, it's encouraging, but we've got a ways to go to really know exactly what we've got.

And on the cash balances, this is Bob Gwin, I think in this kind of an environment, in this kind commodity price environment with these uncertainties, certainly more cash is better than less. We have a fair number of commitments on the mega projects and with the exploration portfolio in the upcoming months.

In addition, I guess on the much smaller size, if we saw something on bolt-on basis in a certain field to enhance our economics or our opportunities to build shareholder value, we'd look for it. Although we love our portfolio the way it is, and so those things will be kind of opportunistic.
And any further plans to raise cash between here and year-end on asset disposals or working interest sales?
No, no interest now. I think that's one of the reasons you saw the equity issuance was because that certainly precluded our need to look at things such as that.
Okay, I'm sorry, one final one. If you had to estimate sort of what that next year or 18 months offshore program CapEx might look like, what is the rough development number to work with?
We are – on the development side, we are using about 130 to $150 million a quarter for the – and I think you are asking for the deepwater portfolio?
You are correct yeah. Okay, terrific. Thank you very much
And your next question comes from the line of Tom Gardner with Simmons & Company. Please proceed.

Thank you, operator. Hey Bob, following up on Ben's question, based on your comments on the risk to Venus, would it be accurate to assume that a success at Venus would partially derisk the C105 block off of Côte d'Ivoire?

I think a success anywhere along here is going to help with the 30 leads and prospects we have got identified. Of course Jubilee derisked a lot of it. That proved up the petroleum system, that proved up the reservoir, the quality and the depositional systems that we have been identifying up and down this margin. So, we are kind of at the other end of what we see as the play at Sierra Leone, and any encouragement there is going to really derisk and help out everything in between. So it's not going to kill anything, but we are going to be learning a lot from this well.

That's good news. Jumping over to the Gulf of Mexico, can you discuss the Vito and Samurai and the likelihood that either will be a tieback versus a standalone and what's the valuation uplift, if you will, of one versus the other, in a general sense?

Yeah, this is Bob again. On the Samurai, we are just 12 miles away from our Marco Polo platform there. We've got capacity and we have always planned on that being a tieback into that almost regardless of how big it was, just because of the capacity that we have. On the Vito well, that one's could be very significant in size, but we do have partners there that have infrastructure around us at Mars and Ersa.

Shell has capacity and so we'll just have to kind of see how big that is, relative to what they have in the way of capacity on those and distance, costs, do the economics on it. But there does seem to be some capacity around that if we wanted to explore that. Of course we will be appraising both of those probably early next year, first quarterish, for both of them is what we're looking at.
Great. One last question, can you give us an update on the Algerian tax arbitration? And how would you handle that from an accounting treatment assuming the arbitration goes your way?

Yeah, this is Bobby Reeves. The arbitration is proceeding. It's not going to be a quick process. We are plodding down the path, and it could be 18 months to two years before we see any kind of decision from an arbitration panel. I'll defer the -

Yeah, and as far as the accounting treatment goes, Tom, until you actually reach resolution, we'll continue on with our current accounting treatment, which is where we record the excess profit tax in our other production tax line, and bear in mind, on the residual effect as you drop that down, that is not deductible for federal tax purposes.
Thank you very much.
And your next comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Howard Weil. You may proceed.

Thank you, good morning guys. A couple of things from me. There has been a lot of moving parts, I guess on your working interest in West Africa. Can you just kind of bring up to date as to what working interest you would expect to drill some of the wells over the next – the next few months, and a related question, my understanding is that you might be trying to at least pursue an increased position in the south deepwater tunnel block with Ikeer. Can you maybe comment on that if indeed there is anything going on there?

I'll start first with the positions that we have now. Of course you know the positions in Ghana with the two blocks there. In Sierra Leone, the Venus flow, we are going to end up at about 40% working interest. We had partners in there originally and then we brought additional partners in through swaps to get into additional acreage. South Grand Lahou we will probably end up with about 50% in that well.

The additional Côte d'Ivoire block, that's going to be – is it 40% – ultimately, that we are going to end up with, and then block 10 in Liberia, we have a 100% presently; we'll probably layoff some of that. The other three Liberian blocks we are bringing some smaller interest partners in as part of the swaps to expand our position. So really we're expanding, not just laying off interest, and we'll end up with the an average 40% working interest across the entire play, when you look at it, and, but what we've ended up with is 8 million acres right through the guts of it.
Great, any comments on the sort of Deepwater Tano block?
I guess the main thing I would say is that that was a bid round. We did bid on that block in the bid round, and Ikeer was awarded it and we have not had additional conservations with them about it.

Okay, great. Thanks for that. The only follow-up I have is jumping back to the Lower 48 and the Eagle Ford, it seems there has been some comments from one of your partners this morning about changes to operatorship. Can you just maybe bring us up to date as to what your plans are? I know that you guys are kind of running the show. And whether or not we'd expect you to accelerate activity down in that region.

I don't think there is going to be any change to our plan. We did pick up an operated rig here a few months ago, I guess. We didn't have to do that, but we saw enough encouragement; we wanted to start that process, and we will probably have a couple rigs running out there to continue to evaluate the Eagle Ford and also to test the Purcell as we go on so, I don't think there is a change. What we wanted to do was have the partnership earn the acreage, spend their money to test it. And meanwhile we saw enough encouragement we wanted to start learning ourselves so we put a rig out there a little early.

Okay, that's great. If I could risk one final one if I may, I'd just jump into the Marcellus. You talked about, in your prepared remarks, Jim, about accelerating your activity levels towards the end of the year. What kind of rights of way do you have right now in terms of, what where you can take your volumes without running into any kind of infrastructure problems?

And, this is Jeff, we have a portion of our position out there in the AMI, with private companies. You have Shell involving in production and we have access to those right of ways in the Eastern portion of our position in AMI with Chesapeake. And we are obtaining that from primarily the state and mostly along previously designated right of ways that and that means power lines or gas lines. It's a process that we are going through. In the early stages of development and exploration, what we've done is take advantage of those, put our locations as near infrastructure as possible, so we can access connections to interstate interconnects, pipelines, etcetera as well as right-of-ways for systems and roads.
Okay, I appreciate the comments. Thanks very much.
And your next question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed.
Thank you, good morning.
Good morning, Brian.

With regards to U.S. natural gas, if we strip out the impacts of pipeline maintenance and potential future hurricane disruptions, where do you see your gas production heading, considering your current reduced activity in the Rockies offset by strong results you're seeing out of the Marcellus?

Well I'll address the first part of your question which is – the impact we are having in the Gulf of Mexico with the hub we do have maintenance and that type of thing going on in the Gulf of Mexico that will affect our third quarter.

Following the third quarter we should see continued growth of our production profile; the Rockies assets are performing extremely well, and almost to the asset, particularly given how capital efficient they've become due to our rig program, they will continue to see growth in Wattenberg, Greater Natural Buttes, Powder River Basin, Wamsutter, Pineville, Jonah, We think we will continue to see growth there and then if you add the Marcellus into the portfolio as we anticipate it coming in, we'll see substantial growth in Marcellus production, so overall I would anticipate that it's up for the foreseeable future.

That's helpful, and actually some of your comments layered into my follow-up, which is when you think about the Rockies portfolio specifically, can you talk about at current gas prices, but also at current low service costs, where are you seeing well economics in places like the PRB and Natural Buttes, and how we should think about your reduced activity. Is that the result of low returns at current gas prices or is a result of more having better opportunities within your global portfolio to spend capital?

It's actually some of both. Each of our major assets in the Rockies, we have focused on the core areas. They have extremely good economics down to very low oil prices and they are aided to a large degree, if you take for instance in Wattenberg and in Greater Natural Buttes, with either the oil order liquids private, we see pretty considerable uplifts to our lease backs, or our net backs at the lease. So, we've had, the economics are very good in the core and that's where we reduced, we've concentrated our reduced drilling fleet in those core areas in each of those assets. In addition, it's competing now with our Marcellus position and Haynesville position as well as the international activities that we've had, so we have taken our capital, we've tried to be as efficient as we possibly can with it. And taken advantage of the best – the best opportunities we have.

Okay, for you to increase your rig count then, would you have to see substantially higher gas prices? Or I guess, given the equity financing and all, where do your priorities lie when you think about if you've got an extra $100 million to spend? Does that definitively get spent in Deepwater versus the Marcellus versus the Rockies?

Brian, this is Al Walker. I think what you would probably see is we would favor short cycle investment opportunities where we think we have got really rates of return. Today that would be both Marcellus and Wattenberg onshore.
Great, thank you.
And your next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Tudor Pickering Holt. Please proceed.

Good morning. Just wanted to speak to a couple of things on the appraisal side at, in Ghana and then also Gulf of Mexico; talked about Heidelberg appraisal, I just wanted to refresh on the Gulf of Mexico side, at Heidelberg, when will you go back out and drill appraisal wells there?

Well, right now, we have got it on the schedule for a September spud. But there may be a little bit of sliding on that based on the rig, but we want to get back on that, and we would like to get it finished by the end of the year.
Okay and they you'd hit both Vito and Samurai is first quarter 2010. Anything else in the Gulf of Mexico that fits into the appraisal or delineation side?

Yeah, ultimately we need to get over to Shenandoah; we're waiting on from new data coming in there. Of course, I mentioned Vito, but we do want to get back over there very quickly, actually, because we did see a lot of potential on that prospect. We have got a lot of updip room and we think that one could be significant to us. So, those will be early, Samurai will be next year and then the Shenandoah will probably be later in the year as we get the data in.

And then on Vito, 20% interest. No, I mean you made the discovery, so no way to really increase your interest now in that updip side or just kind of expect to stick at 20%, is a reasonable expectation?
I would think, I mean which with Shell and Statoil, we've got what we've got.
Yeah, and then on the Ghana side, appraisal drilling there, just kind of get my mind around rig activities that's for exploration versus appraisal and development drilling at Jubilee.

The next three Ghana wells that we have got, that are going to be apprising, would be Tweneboa-2, where we want to see what that really can be, because we've got the updip edge of it on the first well so that could be a real key well for us. Mahogany-4 which is going to take us out to the East, and then the Mahogany Deep, which we also think could have some fairly significant resources there but needs to be appraised. So those would be the next three, then we've got the additional exploratory wells, as Jim mentioned, that will be in 2010. We've just got an awful a lot of activity still to come there in Ghana.

And at Tweneboa-2 really got updip, have a relatively small size. I mean what step of upside could you identify kind of on a, as you derisk the prospect with that well? I mean what's the range of outcomes for that?

David, this is Al Walker, I think the best way to answer that would be Tullow operates that block and is fairly communicative in terms of their views, and I think they see something upwards approaching 1 billion barrels as potential for the discovery.
And they've talked 50 million barrels on the low side, so it's just a wide range in between that.
We've only drilled one well.

And so those are completely separate on a resource standpoint and how you think about Jubilee and Tweneboa, or I guess Mahogany and Tweneboa in the overall development. So, this well could be a larger appraisal as I think about the three that Bob just went through?
Yeah.
Yeah, fair enough. Okay, that was it. Thank you.
And you next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wachovia. Please proceed.

Hi, only a few left. But can we talk about CapEx? If you look at your full-year target that you guys threw out there, you're trending under that. Any outlook on what CapEx looks like for the full year?

David, this is Al Walker. Currently, our spending activities where we operate, we have a pretty good sense for. I think the two areas, both Marcellus and the Gulf of Mexico, are non-op. The activity there is a little more variable, and as a result it's not particularly easy for us to pinpoint that, because we just don't know what the activity level is going to be non-op in both of those places.

The major projects, we continue to see the funding that we have talked about in the past, and I think you can continue to expect that our spending level in the Marcellus will be pretty significant as we've talked about today and in previous discussions.
Okay and then Al, if you look at compared to a year ago, your CapEx, we will call it efficiency today versus then. How's that shaping up and any regions in particular jumping out?

Well, I mean, I think Jim made some comments to that in his prepared remarks. I think the cycle time that we are seeing in the Rockies has been probably the most impressive at Wattenberg, but that's not to take away from some of the stuff in we call it in our Southern region, where we are continuing to see record cycle drilling opportunities develop.

And I continue to believe that the efficiency around our spend is going to be, we've still got some more to come there. I think a lot of the things that we hope to do in the Marcellus is borrowed from what we have learned in the Rockies with pad drilling and planning for development ahead of actually drilling the well, so as get into the Marcellus as an operator, those efficiencies that we've learned in the Rockies, we have worked pretty hard to kind of transfer that to this new play.
All right. Okay thank you.
And your next question comes from the line of Joe Allman with JPMorgan. Please proceed.
Thank you, good morning everybody.
Good morning Joe.
What's the timetable on a decision at the Venus prospect?
The timetable on the decision?
Yeah
Well, we're on the well now.
Sure, I understand, so how long is it going to take to get to TD and come out with a decision on that one?
I would say probably 45 days to get down the boring problems, to get down, get logged, see what we have. They are not long wells out here.
Okay. Great and then, separate topic. Independence Hub. What's the key going forward over the next couple of years to keeping Independence Hub full?

This is Chuck. What we have going on is, there is a number of workovers and additional wells we'll be drilling in and around the hub on existing fields, for example, we are going to drill a new Merganser side track. We have a Cheyenne to east well we'll drilling; we have just worked our way into a Calisto development; and we'll start – we'll be starting all that as we move into the fall. And so through that activity, we should be able to continue to push the hub at or near plateau for another six to eight to twelve months and then see what else we can come up with to add on the back of that.

Okay, that's helpful and then, and Chuck, what's the production capacity now? I mean, like is the production capacity well above the 900 Bcf a day or do you think the wells are pretty much running flat out?

You know the hub has been running right about 900 million a day; that is where it feels good.
